newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican peso ends sharply weaker on rates.
newsitem.headline: Mexican peso ends sharply weaker on rates.

text.p: Mexico's peso recovered from an earlier bout of speculation in late trade on Wednesday but still closed sharply weaker following Tuesday night's falls in primary interest rates, traders said.
"The fall in interest rates was the cue for long-awaited adjustment in the exchange rate, which the export sector, among others, have been asking for," a trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour counterpart were 4.1 and 3.9 centavos weaker, respectively, at 7.5850/7.5890 and 7.5810/7.5850 per dollar.
The 48-hour peso tested support at 7.60 per dollar during the session.
The peso had been under pressure since early trade from dealers covering positions in dollars, and was weakened further by foreign investors stepping out of the money market.

"The importance of all this is that the peso is consolidating at new levels...foreigners are showing signs that they are not interested in renewing money market investments at current rates," another trader said.
Speculative buying of dollars was also partly responsible for weakening the peso and increasing volume compared to recent sessions, traders said.
The same-day peso earlier closed 3.2 centavos weaker at 7.5650/7.5700 per dollar.
Traders expected the dollars in the 48-hour market to be in demand on Thursday, as they do not have to be paid for until after the weekend.
